Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the author of the AITA post is in the wrong. The situation is about rejecting a guy who was honest about her weight gain and then he rejected her for being "too fat" after seeing her body.

First, the author was upfront. She sent full body pictures, even nude, to let him decide if he was attracted. That seems responsible. He was into her personality, and they had a good connection. Then during a face-time, he wanted to see her body again. She showed him, and he made a comment about her being bigger. Then he ignored her for hours, which upset her. When she finally gave up, he came back saying looks matter and she's too fat. She decided not to stay friends because of his behavior.

The key points here are honesty from both sides. The author was transparent about her weight gain. The guy, however, after the initial connection, couldn't get past her appearance. He didn't handle it well by ignoring her instead of being upfront. That lack of communication is a big issue. The author felt disrespected because he didn't just say no directly. She then decided to end the friendship, which makes sense given his actions. 

Is she in the wrong? Well, she didn't do anything unethical. She was honest. He made the choice to prioritize looks and then handled the rejection poorly. The author's decision to cut ties is a personal choice. People have the right to choose who they want to be friends with, especially after such treatment. 

I think the answer is B, the author isn't in the wrong. The guy's behavior was worse here. She was upfront, he wasn't respectful with his communication. Ending the friendship is reasonable.
